choices.text: If hyaline cap becomes more than 2cm in size
If the growth is towards the knee

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling around his right knee which on X-RAY presents as elbow. The treating doctors say it's a benign tumour but it can rarely turn malignant. Which of the following situations should raise suspicion of malignant change?
questions.solution:
The above X-RAY shows osteochondroma

OSTEOCHONDROMA:

  • Exostosis
  • Most common benign tumor
  • Most common benign radiation induced bone tumor
  • Metaphyseal lesion
  • Sessile or pedunculated

Xray features of osteochondroma:

  • Pedicle
  • Growth away from joint line
  • Cortex is continuous
  • Medullary canal continuous
  • Size discrepancy

Clinical presentation:

  • Mostly asymptomatic
  • If pain present may be because of:
    • Bursitis
    • Fracture of exostosis
    • Nerve compression
    • Malignant change (very rare <1% Chondrosarcoma)

Malignant transformation features:

  • Growth after skeletal maturity
  • Pain
  • Loss of cortical and medullary continuity
  • Increased size of cartilage cap (>2cm)
  • Disorganised calcification in the cap

Treatment: observation

Excision in symptomatic patients

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 247

choices.text: Tighten some bed sheets around pelvis

questions.text: A male patient presents with history of RTA. Clinically he has sustained pelvic fracture and is in Hypovolemic shock. What is the first line of management to be followed?
questions.solution:
Primary aim of treatment is resuscitating the patient (ATLS)- ABCDE (airway, breathing, circulation, disability assessment, exposure to environment)

Maintenance of circulation is the most difficult task in pelvic fractures because:

  • Blood loss in pelvic fractures is 1.5 to 2L
  • Causes of bleeding in pelvis fracture:
    • Highly vascular cancellous bone
    • Pelvic venous plexus injuries

How to stop bleeding?

  • Compress the pelvis
  • Tamponade of venous plexus

Pelvic binder

Pelvic external fixator

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 126

questions.text: A 28 yr old was brought to the casualty after RTA. On physical examination, it was found that he had right femoral shaft fracture. The patient was conscious, oriented and vitals were normal. But after 24 hours, he developed confusion, difficulty in breathing and rashes over axilla and chest. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

This is one of the most serious complications, the essential feature being occlusion of small vessels by fat globules.

Causes: The fat globules may originate from bone marrow or adipose tissue. Fat embolism is more common following severe injuries with multiple fractures and fractures of major bones. The pathogenesis of the syndrome is not clear, but it seems likely that two events occur: (i) release of free fatty acids (by action of lipases on the neutral fat), which induces a toxic vasculitis, followed by platelet-fibrin thrombosis; and (ii) actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Consequences: Symptoms are evident a day or so after the injury. Presenting features are in the form of two, more or less distinct types: (i) cerebral; and (ii) pulmonary. In the cerebral type, the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma. In the pulmonary type, tachypnoea and tachycardia are the more prominent features. The other common feature of fat embolism is a patechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Diagnosis: In a case with multiple fractures, early diagnosis may be possible by strong suspicion. In addition to the classic clinical features, signs of retinal artery emboli (striate haemorrhages and exudates) may be present. Sputum and urine may reveal the presence of fat globules. X-ray of the chest may show a patchy pulmonary infiltration (snow storm appearance). Blood PO 2 of less than 50 mmHg may indicate impending respiratory failure.

GURD's criteria used for fat embolism syndrome

Treatment: This consists of respiratory support, heparinisation, intravenous low molecular weight dextran (Lomodex-20) and corticosteroids. An intravenous 5 percent dextrose solution with 5 percent alcohol helps in emulsification of fat globules, and is used by some.

Refrence: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 43

questions.text: 32-year-old patient came in emergency with bump on his right shoulder after RTA. His X-RAY is given below. Which ligament is associated with this injury?
questions.solution:
the above X-RAY shows-acromio-clavicular joint dislocation

Acromio clavicular joint is stabilised by:

  1. Coracoclavicular ligament
  2. Acromioclavicular ligament
  3. Coracoclavicular acromial ligament3


The injury may result in a partial or complete rupture of the acromio-clavicular or coracoclavicular ligaments. Acromio-clavicular joint injuries are divided into three grades depending upon their severity

Treatment: Grades I and II injuries are treated by rest in a triangular sling and analgesics. Grade III injury in young athletic individuals is treated by surgical repair.

Reference: maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no -89

questions.text: A 14yr old boy came to the OPD with pain and swelling in the thighs, legs and arm bones. Bone scan revealed increased uptake in the skull, ribs, vertebrae, radius, ulna, femur, tibia and fibula. Skin rashes were also present. Proximal femur shows bending of the proximal end. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mc-Cune Albright syndrome:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (unilateral)
  • Cafe-au lait spots (coast of Maine)
  • Precocious puberty

Reference: maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no -249

questions.text: what is this test done before making an arteriovenous fistula in the wrist?
questions.solution:
The above given image is of ALLEN'S TEST: test for latency of radial and ulnar arteries at wrist

Rationale: to make sure that the ulnar artery is patent before doing a procedure on radial artery and vice versa. Risk of gangrene if we interfere with only patent vessel

Indications for this test:

  • AV fistula for dialysis
  • Radial artery harvesting- CABG
  • Radial artery based muscle flaps
  • Radial artery catheterisation

Wright test, adson test, Roos test are tests for thoracic outlet syndrome

Reference : sabiston 21st edition pg no 1949

questions.text: A 65 years old postmenopausal female came with persistent backache not responding to conservative treatment. History of lifting heavy weight 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking. The pain starts radiating down her legs after walking for around 100m distance, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs, most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In most condition pain will increase on climbing up stairs. The one exception is lumbar canal stenosis, where there is relief in pain when the patients climb up stairs.

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

  • Chronic condition characterised by narrowing of lumbar spinal canal causing compression of spinal cord or its emerging nerve roots
  • Most common location: L4-L5
  • Age- >65 yrs
  • Lumbar Canal stenosis is the most common reason for lumbar spine surgery in patients >65yrs
  • Males>females
  • Causes of lumbar canal stenosis:
    • Degenerative/spondylotic changes (most common)
    • Intervertebral disc prolapse
    • Post surgical
    • Vertebral fractures
    • Inflammatory: ankylosing spondylitis
    • Secondary to systemic disease- paget disease, acromegaly, fluorosis

Clinical features of lumbar canal stenosis:

  • Back pain
  • Radiation to one\both lower limbs
  • Buttock pain
  • Bowel bladder symptoms
  • Neurogenic claudication

Neurogenic claudication:

  • In lumbar canal stenosis, neurogenic claudication pain is the hall mark (i.e. pain arising in the lower back radiating down the buttock, thigh, leg to the foot especially on prolonged physical activity).
  • Pain worsens on standing or walking but is generally relieved by either bending forwards (trunk flexion) or sitting. Posture related pain in LCS is due to the fact that the available space in the central canal decreases in axial loading and extension and increases in axial distraction and flexion. this also explains that why do patients get more relief in lying on the side (allowing flexion posture) than lying flat.

For the same reason patients and walking uphill easier and pushing a shopping cart gives them relief (positive shopping cart sign) . Since they mostly remain stooped forwards to relieve pressure on their neural structures, their posture is said to be Ape like.

Differentials

An important differential is vascular claudication pain (i.e. pain due to a peripheral artery disease). Pain on standing alone is the most sensitive symptom to differentiate neurogenic claudication from vascular claudication.

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain page no 186.
